components.name: slider
components.title: Angular Slider Component
components.description: Slider is a component to provide input with a drag handle.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Slider element component uses slider role on the handle in addition to the aria-orientation , aria-valuemin , aria-valuemax and aria-valuenow attributes. Value to describe the component can be defined using ariaLabelledBy and ariaLabel props.

examples.basic: Number

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Two-way binding is defined using the standard ngModel directive.

examples.basic: <p-slider [(ngModel)]="value" class="w-56" />

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: Image filter implementation using multiple sliders.

sections.label: Input
sections.description: Slider is connected to an input field using two-way binding.

sections.label: Range
sections.description: When range property is present, slider provides two handles to define two values. In range mode, value should be an array instead of a single value.

examples.basic: <p-slider [(ngModel)]="rangeValues" [range]="true" class="w-56" />

sections.label: reactiveforms-doc
sections.description: Slider can also be used with reactive forms. In this case, the formControlName property is used to bind the component to a form control.

examples.basic: @if (isInvalid('value')) { Must be greater than 25. }
examples.html: @if (isInvalid('value')) { Must be greater than 25. }

sections.label: Step
sections.description: Size of each movement is defined with the step property.

examples.basic: <p-slider [(ngModel)]="value" [step]="20" class="w-56" />
@if (model.invalid && (model.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Must be greater than 25. }
examples.html: @if (model.invalid && (model.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Must be greater than 25. }

sections.label: Vertical
sections.description: Default layout of slider is horizontal , use orientation property for the alternative vertical mode.

examples.basic: <p-slider [(ngModel)]="value" orientation="vertical" class="h-56" />

components.name: speeddial
components.title: Angular Speed Dial Component
components.description: SpeedDial is a floating button with a popup menu.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader SpeedDial component renders a native button element that implicitly includes any passed prop. Text to describe the button can be defined with the aria-labelledby or aria-label props. Addititonally the button includes includes aria-haspopup , aria-expanded for states along with aria-controls to define the relation between the popup and the button. The popup overlay uses menu role on the list and each action item has a menuitem role with an aria-label as the menuitem label. The id of the menu refers to the aria-controls of the button.

examples.basic: <p-speeddial aria-label="Options" />

sections.label: Circle
sections.description: Items can be displayed around the button when type is set to circle . Additional radius property defines the radius of the circle.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-speeddial [model]="items" [radius]="80" type="circle" [style]="{ position: 'absolute' }" [buttonProps]="{ severity: 'warn', rounded: true }" />

sections.label: Linear
sections.description: SpeedDial items are defined with the model property based on MenuModel API. Default orientation of the items is linear and direction property is used to define the position of the items related to the button.

sections.label: Mask
sections.description: Adding mask property displays a modal layer behind the popup items.

sections.label: Quarter Circle
sections.description: When type is defined as quarter-circle , items are displayed in a half-circle around the button.

sections.label: Semi Circle
sections.description: When type is defined as semi-circle , items are displayed in a half-circle around the button.

sections.label: Template
sections.description: SpeedDial offers item customization with the item template that receives the menuitem instance from the model as a parameter. The button has its own button template, additional template named icon is provided to embed icon content for default button.

examples.basic: {{ item.label }}
examples.html: {{ item.label }}

sections.label: Tooltip
sections.description: Items display a tooltip on hover when a standalone Tooltip is present with a target that matches the items.

components.name: splitbutton
components.title: Angular SplitButton Component
components.description: SplitButton groups a set of commands in an overlay with a default action item.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader SplitButton component renders two native button elements, main button uses the label property to define aria-label by default which can be customized with buttonProps . Dropdown button requires an explicit definition to describe it using menuButtonProps option and also includes aria-haspopup , aria-expanded for states along with aria-controls to define the relation between the popup and the button. The popup overlay uses menu role on the list and each action item has a menuitem role with an aria-label as the menuitem label. The id of the menu refers to the aria-controls of the dropdown button.

examples.basic: <p-splitbutton [buttonProps]="{'aria-label': 'Default Action'}" [menuButtonProps]="{'aria-label': 'More Options'}" />

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: SplitButton has a default action button and a collection of additional options defined by the model property based on MenuModel API.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-splitbutton label="Save" (onClick)="save()" [model]="items" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When the disabled attribute is present, the element is uneditable and unfocused. Additionally, the disabled states of the button and menu button can be handled independently. The button is disabled when buttonDisabled is present, and the menu button is disabled when menuButtonDisabled is present.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-splitbutton label="Save" icon="pi pi-plus" (onClick)="save('info')" [model]="items" [disabled]="true" />

sections.label: Icons
sections.description: The buttons and menuitems have support to display icons.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-splitbutton label="Save" icon="pi pi-check" dropdownIcon="pi pi-cog" [model]="items" />

sections.label: Nested
sections.description: SplitButton has a default action button and a collection of additional options defined by the model property based on MenuModel API.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-splitbutton label="Save" (onClick)="save('info')" [model]="items" />

sections.label: Outlined
sections.description: Outlined buttons display a border without a background initially.

components.name: splitter
components.title: Angular Splitter Component
components.description: Splitter is utilized to separate and resize panels.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Splitter bar defines separator as the role with aria-orientation set to either horizontal or vertical. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the splitter bar. down arrow Moves a vertical splitter down. up arrow Moves a vertical splitter up. left arrow Moves a vertical splitter to the left. right arrow Moves a vertical splitter to the right.

sections.label: Horizontal

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Stepper container is defined with the tablist role, as any attribute is passed to the container element aria-labelledby can be optionally used to specify an element to describe the Stepper. Each stepper header has a tab role and aria-controls to refer to the corresponding stepper content element. The content element of each stepper has tabpanel role, an id to match the aria-controls of the header and aria-labelledby reference to the header as the accessible name. Tab Header Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the header. enter Activates the focused stepper header. space Activates the focused stepper header.

sections.description: When hideOnResize is enabled, the leave animation is triggered automatically when resizing occurs. Use the resizeSelector property to specify whether to listen to window resize events or element-specific resize events. components.name: table
components.title: Angular Table Component
components.description: Table displays data in tabular format.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Default role of the table is table . Header, body and footer elements use rowgroup , rows use row role, header cells have columnheader and body cells use cell roles. Sortable headers utilizer aria-sort attribute either set to "ascending" or "descending". Table rows and table cells should be specified by users using the aria-posinset , aria-setsize , aria-label , and aria-describedby attributes, as they are determined through templating. Built-in checkbox and radiobutton components for row selection use checkbox and radiobutton . The label to describe them is retrieved from the aria.selectRow and aria.unselectRow properties of the locale API. Similarly header checkbox uses selectAll and unselectAll keys. When a row is selected, aria-selected is set to true on a row. The element to expand or collapse a row is a button with aria-expanded and aria-controls properties. Value to describe the buttons is derived from aria.expandRow and aria.collapseRow properties of the locale API. The filter menu button use aria.showFilterMenu and aria.hideFilterMenu properties as aria-label in addition to the aria-haspopup , aria-expanded and aria-controls to define the relation between the button and the overlay. Popop menu has dialog role with aria-modal as focus is kept within the overlay. The operator dropdown use aria.filterOperator and filter constraints dropdown use aria.filterConstraint properties. Buttons to add rules on the other hand utilize aria.addRule and aria.removeRule properties. The footer buttons similarly use aria.clear and aria.apply properties. filterInputProps of the Column component can be used to define aria labels for the built-in filter components, if a custom component is used with templating you also may define your own aria labels as well. Editable cells use custom templating so you need to manage aria roles and attributes manually if required. The row editor controls are button elements with aria.editRow , aria.cancelEdit and aria.saveEdit used for the aria-label . Paginator is a standalone component used inside the Table, refer to the paginator for more information about the accessibility features. Keyboard Support Any button element inside the Table used for cases like filter, row expansion, edit are tabbable and can be used with space and enter keys. Sortable Headers Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves through the headers. enter Sorts the column. space Sorts the column. Filter Menu Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves through the elements inside the popup. escape Hides the popup. enter Opens the popup. Selection Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the first selected row, if there is none then first row receives the focus. up arrow Moves focus to the previous row. down arrow Moves focus to the next row. enter Toggles the selected state of the focused row depending on the metaKeySelection setting. space Toggles the selected state of the focused row depending on the metaKeySelection setting. home Moves focus to the first row. end Moves focus to the last row. shift + down arrow Moves focus to the next row and toggles the selection state. shift + up arrow Moves focus to the previous row and toggles the selection state. shift + space Selects the rows between the most recently selected row and the focused row. control + shift + home Selects the focused rows and all the options up to the first one. control + shift + end Selects the focused rows and all the options down to the last one. control + a Selects all rows.

sections.label: contextmenu-doc
sections.description: Table has exclusive integration with contextmenu component. In order to attach a menu to a table, add pContextMenuRow directive to the rows that can be selected with context menu, define a local template variable for the menu and bind it to the contextMenu property of the table. This enables displaying the menu whenever a row is right clicked. Optional pContextMenuRowIndex property is available to access the row index. A separate contextMenuSelection property is used to get a hold of the right clicked row. For dynamic columns, setting pContextMenuRowDisabled property as true disables context menu for that particular row.

sections.label: filterbasic-doc
sections.description: Data filtering is enabled by defining the filters property referring to a DataTableFilterMeta instance. Each column to filter also requires filter to be enabled. Built-in filter element is a input field and using filterElement , it is possible to customize the filtering with your own UI. The optional global filtering searches the data against a single value that is bound to the global key of the filters object. The fields to search against is defined with the globalFilterFields .

`, standalone: true, imports: [SelectModule, IconFieldModule, InputIconModule, MultiSelectModule, TableModule, TagModule, InputTextModule, FormsModule], providers: [CustomerService] }) export class TableFilterbasicDemo implements OnInit { private customerService = inject(CustomerService); customers!: Customer[]; representatives!: Representative[]; statuses!: any[]; loading: boolean = true; activityValues: number[] = [0, 100]; ngOnInit() { this.customerService.getCustomersLarge().then((customers) => { this.customers = customers; this.loading = false; this.customers.forEach((customer) => (customer.date = new Date(customer.date))); }); this.representatives = [ { name: 'Amy Elsner', image: 'amyelsner.png' }, { name: 'Anna Fali', image: 'annafali.png' }, { name: 'Asiya Javayant', image: 'asiyajavayant.png' }, { name: 'Bernardo Dominic', image: 'bernardodominic.png' }, { name: 'Elwin Sharvill', image: 'elwinsharvill.png' }, { name: 'Ioni Bowcher', image: 'ionibowcher.png' }, { name: 'Ivan Magalhaes', image: 'ivanmagalhaes.png' }, { name: 'Onyama Limba', image: 'onyamalimba.png' }, { name: 'Stephen Shaw', image: 'stephenshaw.png' }, { name: 'Xuxue Feng', image: 'xuxuefeng.png' } ]; this.statuses = [ { label: 'Unqualified', value: 'unqualified' }, { label: 'Qualified', value: 'qualified' }, { label: 'New', value: 'new' }, { label: 'Negotiation', value: 'negotiation' }, { label: 'Renewal', value: 'renewal' }, { label: 'Proposal', value: 'proposal' } ]; } clear(table: Table) { table.clear(); } getSeverity(status: string) { switch (status) { case 'unqualified': return 'danger'; case 'qualified': return 'success'; case 'new': return 'info'; case 'negotiation': return 'warn'; case 'renewal': return null; } } }

sections.label: Reorder
sections.description: Order of the columns and rows can be changed using drag and drop. Column reordering is configured by adding reorderableColumns property. Similarly, adding reorderableRows property enables draggable rows. For the drag handle a column needs to have rowReorder property and onRowReorder callback is required to control the state of the rows after reorder completes.

sections.label: rowedit-doc
sections.description: Row editing toggles the visibility of all the editors in the row at once and provides additional options to save and cancel editing. Row editing functionality is enabled by setting the editMode to "row" on table, defining a dataKey to uniquely identify a row, adding pEditableRow directive to the editable rows and defining the UI Controls with pInitEditableRow , pSaveEditableRow and pCancelEditableRow directives respectively. Save and Cancel functionality implementation is left to the page author to provide more control over the editing business logic. Example below utilizes a simple implementation where a row is cloned when editing is initialized and is saved or restored depending on the result of the editing. An implicit variable called "editing" is passed to the body template so you may come up with your own UI controls that implement editing based on your own requirements such as adding validations and styling. Note that pSaveEditableRow only switches the row to back view mode when there are no validation errors. Moreover, you may use setting pEditableRowDisabled property as true to disable editing for that particular row and in case you need to display rows in edit mode by default, use the editingRowKeys property which is a map whose key is the dataKey of the record where the value is any arbitrary number greater than zero.

sections.label: rowexpansion-doc
sections.description: Row expansion allows displaying detailed content for a particular row. To use this feature, define a dataKey , add a template named expandedrow and use the pRowToggler directive on an element as the target to toggle an expansion. This enables providing your custom UI such as buttons, links and so on. Example below uses an anchor with an icon as a toggler. Setting pRowTogglerDisabled as true disables the toggle event for the element.

sections.label: Stateful
sections.description: Stateful table allows keeping the state such as page, sort and filtering either at local storage or session storage so that when the page is visited again, table would render the data using the last settings. Change the state of the table e.g paginate, navigate away and then return to this table again to test this feature, the setting is set as session with the stateStorage property so that Table retains the state until the browser is closed. Other alternative is local referring to localStorage for an extended lifetime.

props.name: dt
props.description: Defines scoped design tokens of the component.

props.name: unstyled
props.description: Indicates whether the component should be rendered without styles.

props.name: pt
props.description: Used to pass attributes to DOM elements inside the component.

props.name: ptOptions
props.description: Used to configure passthrough(pt) options of the component.

props.name: frozenColumns
props.description: An array of objects to represent dynamic columns that are frozen.

props.name: frozenValue
props.description: An array of objects to display as frozen.

props.name: styleClass
props.description: Style class of the component.

props.name: tableStyle
props.description: Inline style of the table.

props.name: tableStyleClass
props.description: Style class of the table.

props.name: paginator
props.description: When specified as true, enables the pagination.

props.name: pageLinks
props.description: Number of page links to display in paginator.

props.name: rowsPerPageOptions
props.description: Array of integer/object values to display inside rows per page dropdown of paginator

props.name: alwaysShowPaginator
props.description: Whether to show it even there is only one page.

props.name: paginatorPosition
props.description: Position of the paginator, options are "top", "bottom" or "both".

props.name: paginatorStyleClass
props.description: Custom style class for paginator

props.name: paginatorDropdownAppendTo
props.description: Target element to attach the paginator dropdown overlay, valid values are "body" or a local ng-template variable of another element (note: use binding with brackets for template variables, e.g. [appendTo]="mydiv" for a div element having #mydiv as variable name).

props.name: paginatorDropdownScrollHeight
props.description: Paginator dropdown height of the viewport in pixels, a scrollbar is defined if height of list exceeds this value.

props.name: currentPageReportTemplate
props.description: Template of the current page report element. Available placeholders are {currentPage},{totalPages},{rows},{first},{last} and {totalRecords}

props.name: showCurrentPageReport
props.description: Whether to display current page report.

props.name: showJumpToPageDropdown
props.description: Whether to display a dropdown to navigate to any page.

props.name: showJumpToPageInput
props.description: Whether to display a input to navigate to any page.

props.name: showFirstLastIcon
props.description: When enabled, icons are displayed on paginator to go first and last page.

props.name: showPageLinks
props.description: Whether to show page links.

props.name: defaultSortOrder
props.description: Sort order to use when an unsorted column gets sorted by user interaction.

props.name: sortMode
props.description: Defines whether sorting works on single column or on multiple columns.

props.name: resetPageOnSort
props.description: When true, resets paginator to first page after sorting. Available only when sortMode is set to single.

props.name: selectionMode
props.description: Specifies the selection mode, valid values are "single" and "multiple".

props.name: selectionPageOnly
props.description: When enabled with paginator and checkbox selection mode, the select all checkbox in the header will select all rows on the current page.

props.name: contextMenuSelection
props.description: Selected row with a context menu.

props.name: contextMenuSelectionMode
props.description: Defines the behavior of context menu selection, in "separate" mode context menu updates contextMenuSelection property whereas in joint mode selection property is used instead so that when row selection is enabled, both row selection and context menu selection use the same property.

props.name: dataKey
props.description: A property to uniquely identify a record in data.

props.name: metaKeySelection
props.description: Defines whether metaKey should be considered for the selection. On touch enabled devices, metaKeySelection is turned off automatically.

props.name: rowSelectable
props.description: Defines if the row is selectable.

props.name: rowTrackBy
props.description: Function to optimize the dom operations by delegating to ngForTrackBy, default algorithm checks for object identity.

props.name: lazy
props.description: Defines if data is loaded and interacted with in lazy manner.

props.name: lazyLoadOnInit
props.description: Whether to call lazy loading on initialization.

props.name: compareSelectionBy
props.description: Algorithm to define if a row is selected, valid values are "equals" that compares by reference and "deepEquals" that compares all fields.

props.name: csvSeparator
props.description: Character to use as the csv separator.

props.name: exportFilename
props.description: Name of the exported file.

props.name: filters
props.description: An array of FilterMetadata objects to provide external filters.

props.name: globalFilterFields
props.description: An array of fields as string to use in global filtering.

props.name: filterDelay
props.description: Delay in milliseconds before filtering the data.

props.name: filterLocale
props.description: Locale to use in filtering. The default locale is the host environment's current locale.

props.name: expandedRowKeys
props.description: Map instance to keep the expanded rows where key of the map is the data key of the row.

props.name: editingRowKeys
props.description: Map instance to keep the rows being edited where key of the map is the data key of the row.

props.name: rowExpandMode
props.description: Whether multiple rows can be expanded at any time. Valid values are "multiple" and "single".

props.name: scrollable
props.description: Enables scrollable tables.

props.name: rowGroupMode
props.description: Type of the row grouping, valid values are "subheader" and "rowspan".

props.name: scrollHeight
props.description: Height of the scroll viewport in fixed pixels or the "flex" keyword for a dynamic size.

props.name: virtualScroll
props.description: Whether the data should be loaded on demand during scroll.

props.name: virtualScrollItemSize
props.description: Height of a row to use in calculations of virtual scrolling.

props.name: virtualScrollOptions
props.description: Whether to use the scroller feature. The properties of scroller component can be used like an object in it.

props.name: virtualScrollDelay
props.description: Threshold in milliseconds to delay lazy loading during scrolling.

props.name: frozenWidth
props.description: Width of the frozen columns container.

props.name: contextMenu
props.description: Local ng-template varilable of a ContextMenu.

props.name: resizableColumns
props.description: When enabled, columns can be resized using drag and drop.

props.name: columnResizeMode
props.description: Defines whether the overall table width should change on column resize, valid values are "fit" and "expand".

props.name: reorderableColumns
props.description: When enabled, columns can be reordered using drag and drop.

props.name: loading
props.description: Displays a loader to indicate data load is in progress.

props.name: loadingIcon
props.description: The icon to show while indicating data load is in progress.

props.name: showLoader
props.description: Whether to show the loading mask when loading property is true.

props.name: rowHover
props.description: Adds hover effect to rows without the need for selectionMode. Note that tr elements that can be hovered need to have "p-selectable-row" class for rowHover to work.

props.name: customSort
props.description: Whether to use the default sorting or a custom one using sortFunction.

props.name: showInitialSortBadge
props.description: Whether to use the initial sort badge or not.

props.name: exportFunction
props.description: Export function.

props.name: exportHeader
props.description: Custom export header of the column to be exported as CSV.

props.name: stateKey
props.description: Unique identifier of a stateful table to use in state storage.

props.name: stateStorage
props.description: Defines where a stateful table keeps its state, valid values are "session" for sessionStorage and "local" for localStorage.

props.name: editMode
props.description: Defines the editing mode, valid values are "cell" and "row".

props.name: groupRowsBy
props.description: Field name to use in row grouping.

props.name: size
props.description: Defines the size of the table.

props.name: showGridlines
props.description: Whether to show grid lines between cells.

props.name: stripedRows
props.description: Whether to display rows with alternating colors.

props.name: groupRowsByOrder
props.description: Order to sort when default row grouping is enabled.

props.name: responsiveLayout
props.description: Defines the responsive mode, valid options are "stack" and "scroll".
props.deprecated: since v20.0.0, always defaults to scroll, stack mode needs custom implementation

props.name: breakpoint
props.description: The breakpoint to define the maximum width boundary when using stack responsive layout.

props.name: paginatorLocale
props.description: Locale to be used in paginator formatting.

props.name: value
props.description: An array of objects to display.

props.name: columns
props.description: An array of objects to represent dynamic columns.

props.name: first
props.description: Index of the first row to be displayed.

props.name: rows
props.description: Number of rows to display per page.

props.name: totalRecords
props.description: Number of total records, defaults to length of value when not defined.

props.name: sortField
props.description: Name of the field to sort data by default.

props.name: sortOrder
props.description: Order to sort when default sorting is enabled.

props.name: multiSortMeta
props.description: An array of SortMeta objects to sort the data by default in multiple sort mode.

props.name: selection
props.description: Selected row in single mode or an array of values in multiple mode.

props.name: selectAll
props.description: Whether all data is selected.

emits.name: contextMenuSelectionChange
emits.description: Callback to invoke on context menu selection change.

emits.name: selectAllChange
emits.description: Emits when the all of the items selected or unselected.

emits.name: selectionChange
emits.description: Callback to invoke on selection changed.

emits.name: onRowSelect
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is selected.

emits.name: onRowUnselect
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is unselected.

emits.name: onPage
emits.description: Callback to invoke when pagination occurs.

emits.name: onSort
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a column gets sorted.

emits.name: onFilter
emits.description: Callback to invoke when data is filtered.

emits.name: onLazyLoad
emits.description: Callback to invoke when paging, sorting or filtering happens in lazy mode.

emits.name: onRowExpand
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is expanded.

emits.name: onRowCollapse
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is collapsed.

emits.name: onContextMenuSelect
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is selected with right click.

emits.name: onColResize
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a column is resized.

emits.name: onColReorder
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a column is reordered.

emits.name: onRowReorder
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a row is reordered.

emits.name: onEditInit
emits.description: Callback to invoke when a cell switches to edit mode.

emits.name: onEditComplete
emits.description: Callback to invoke when cell edit is completed.

emits.name: onEditCancel
emits.description: Callback to invoke when cell edit is cancelled with escape key.

emits.name: onHeaderCheckboxToggle
emits.description: Callback to invoke when state of header checkbox changes.

emits.name: sortFunction
emits.description: A function to implement custom sorting, refer to sorting section for details.

emits.name: firstChange
emits.description: Callback to invoke on pagination.

emits.name: rowsChange
emits.description: Callback to invoke on rows change.

emits.name: onStateSave
emits.description: Callback to invoke table state is saved.

emits.name: onStateRestore
emits.description: Callback to invoke table state is restored.

methods.description: Scrolls to given index when using virtual scroll.

components.name: tabs
components.title: Angular Tabs Component
components.description: Tabs is a container component to group content with tabs.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Tabs container is defined with the tablist role, as any attribute is passed to the container element aria-labelledby can be optionally used to specify an element to describe the Tabs. Each tab header has a tab role along with aria-selected state attribute and aria-controls to refer to the corresponding tab content element. The content element of each tab has tabpanel role, an id to match the aria-controls of the header and aria-labelledby reference to the header as the accessible name. Tab Header Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the header. enter Activates the focused tab header. space Activates the focused tab header. right arrow Moves focus to the next header. left arrow Moves focus to the previous header. home Moves focus to the last header. end Moves focus to the first header.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Tabs is defined using TabList , Tab , TabPanels and TabPanel components. Tab and TabPanel components are associated with their value properties

sections.label: Lazy
sections.description: By default, inactive tab's content is rendered (but hidden). You can use the lazy input (either globally on Tabs or individually on a TabPanel ) to change this behavior so that content is only rendered when the tab becomes active. If a lazy tab contains complex components that should only be initialized when the tab is activated, you should wrap the content inside: <ng-template #content>your content</ng-template> .

components.name: tag
components.title: Angular Tag Component
components.description: Tag component is used to categorize content.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Tag does not include any roles and attributes by default, any attribute is passed to the root element so aria roles and attributes can be added if required. If the tags are dynamic, aria-live may be utilized as well. In case badges need to be tabbable, tabIndex can be added to implement custom key handlers. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Label of the tag is defined with the value property.

examples.basic: <p-tag value="New" />

sections.label: Icon
sections.description: A font icon next to the value can be displayed with the icon property.

examples.basic:
<p-tag icon="pi pi-user" value="Primary" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-search" severity="secondary" value="Secondary" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-check" severity="success" value="Success" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-info-circle" severity="info" value="Info" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-exclamation-triangle" severity="warn" value="Warn" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-times" severity="danger" value="Danger" />
<p-tag icon="pi pi-cog" severity="contrast" value="Contrast" />

sections.label: Pill
sections.description: Enabling rounded , displays a tag as a pill.

examples.basic:
<p-tag value="Primary" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="secondary" value="Secondary" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="success" value="Success" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="info" value="Info" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="warn" value="Warn" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="danger" value="Danger" [rounded]="true" />
<p-tag severity="contrast" value="Contrast" [rounded]="true" />

sections.label: Severity
sections.description: Severity defines the color of the tag, possible values are success , info , warn and danger in addition to the default theme color.

examples.basic:
<p-tag value="Primary" />
<p-tag severity="secondary" value="Secondary" />
<p-tag severity="success" value="Success" />
<p-tag severity="info" value="Info" />
<p-tag severity="warn" value="Warn" />
<p-tag severity="danger" value="Danger" />
<p-tag severity="contrast" value="Contrast" />

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Terminal component has an input element that can be described with aria-label or aria-labelledby props. The element that lists the previous commands has aria-live so that changes are received by the screen reader. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the input element. enter Executes the command when focus in on the input element.

sections.label: Basic

components.name: textarea
components.title: Angular Textarea Component
components.description: Textarea adds styling and autoResize functionality to standard textarea element.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Textarea component renders a native textarea element that implicitly includes any passed prop. Value to describe the component can either be provided via label tag combined with id prop or using aria-labelledby , aria-label props.

examples.basic: Address 2

sections.label: AutoResize
sections.description: When autoResize is enabled, textarea grows instead of displaying a scrollbar.

examples.basic: <textarea rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea [autoResize]="true"></textarea>

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Textarea is applied to an input field with pTextarea directive.

examples.basic: <textarea rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value"></textarea>

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <textarea rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea [disabled]="true"></textarea>

sections.label: Filled
sections.description: Specify the variant property as filled to display the component with a higher visual emphasis than the default outlined style.

examples.basic: <textarea [(ngModel)]="value" [variant]="'filled'" rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea></textarea>

sections.label: Float Label
sections.description: A floating label appears on top of the input field when focused. Visit FloatLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<p-floatlabel>
    <textarea pTextarea id="over_label" [(ngModel)]="value1" rows="5" cols="30" style="resize: none" class="h-full"></textarea>
    <label for="over_label">Over Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>
<p-floatlabel variant="in">
    <textarea pTextarea id="in_label" [(ngModel)]="value2" rows="5" cols="30" style="resize: none" class="h-full"></textarea>
    <label for="in_label">In Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>
<p-floatlabel variant="on">
    <textarea pTextarea id="on_label" [(ngModel)]="value3" rows="5" cols="30" style="resize: none" class="h-full"></textarea>
    <label for="on_label">On Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <textarea rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value" fluid></textarea>

sections.label: Ifta Label
sections.description: IftaLabel is used to create infield top aligned labels. Visit IftaLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<p-iftalabel>
    <textarea pTextarea id="description" [(ngModel)]="value" rows="5" cols="30" style="resize: none"></textarea>
    <label for="description">Description</label>
</p-iftalabel>

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: The invalid state is applied using the invalid property to indicate failed validation, which can be integrated with Angular Forms.

examples.basic: <textarea rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value" [invalid]="!value" placeholder="Address"></textarea>

sections.label: keyfilter-doc
sections.description: InputText has built-in key filtering support to block certain keys, refer to keyfilter page for more information.

examples.basic: <textarea pKeyFilter="int" rows="5" cols="30" pTextarea></textarea>

sections.label: reactiveforms-doc
sections.description: Textarea can also be used with reactive forms. In this case, the formControlName property is used to bind the component to a form control.

examples.basic: @if (isInvalid('address')) { Address is required.. }
examples.html: @if (isInvalid('address')) { Address is required.. }

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: Textarea provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

examples.basic:
<textarea pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value1" pSize="small" placeholder="Small" rows="3"></textarea>
<textarea pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value2" placeholder="Normal" rows="3"></textarea>
<textarea pTextarea [(ngModel)]="value3" pSize="large" placeholder="Large" rows="3"></textarea>
@if (address.invalid && (address.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Address is required. }
examples.html: @if (address.invalid && (address.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Address is required. }

components.name: tieredmenu
components.title: Angular TieredMenu Component
components.description: TieredMenu displays submenus in nested overlays.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader TieredMenu component uses the menubar role with aria-orientation set to "vertical" and the value to describe the menu can either be provided with aria-labelledby or aria-label props. Each list item has a presentation role whereas anchor elements have a menuitem role with aria-label referring to the label of the item and aria-disabled defined if the item is disabled. A submenu within a TieredMenu uses the menu role with an aria-labelledby defined as the id of the submenu root menuitem label. In addition, menuitems that open a submenu have aria-haspopup , aria-expanded and aria-controls to define the relation between the item and the submenu. In popup mode, the component implicitly manages the aria-expanded , aria-haspopup and aria-controls attributes of the target element to define the relation between the target and the popup. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Add focus to the first item if focus moves in to the menu. If the focus is already within the menu, focus moves to the next focusable item in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Add focus to the last item if focus moves in to the menu. If the focus is already within the menu, focus moves to the previous focusable item in the page tab sequence. enter If menuitem has a submenu, toggles the visibility of the submenu otherwise activates the menuitem and closes all open overlays. space If menuitem has a submenu, toggles the visibility of the submenu otherwise activates the menuitem and closes all open overlays. escape If focus is inside a popup submenu, closes the submenu and moves focus to the root item of the closed submenu. down arrow Moves focus to the next menuitem within the submenu. up arrow Moves focus to the previous menuitem within the submenu. right arrow Opens a submenu if there is one available and moves focus to the first item. left arrow Closes a submenu and moves focus to the root item of the closed submenu. home Moves focus to the first menuitem within the submenu. end Moves focus to the last menuitem within the submenu.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: TieredMenu requires a collection of menuitems as its model .

examples.basic: <p-tieredmenu [model]="items" />

sections.label: Command
sections.description: The command property defines the callback to run when an item is activated by click or a key event.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-tieredmenu [model]="items" />

sections.label: Popup
sections.description: Popup mode is enabled by adding popup property and calling toggle method with an event of the target.

examples.basic:
<p-button label="Toggle" (click)="menu.toggle($event)" />
<p-tieredmenu #menu [model]="items" [popup]="true" />

sections.label: Router
sections.description: Menu items support navigation via routerLink, programmatic routing using commands, or external URLs.

examples.basic: <p-tieredmenu [model]="items" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: TieredMenu offers item customization with the item template that receives the menuitem instance from the model as a parameter.

examples.basic: {{ item.label }} {{ item.shortcut }}
examples.html: {{ item.label }} {{ item.shortcut }}

components.name: timeline
components.title: Angular Timeline Component
components.description: Timeline visualizes a series of chained events.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Timeline uses a semantic ordered list element to list the events. No specific role is enforced, still you may use any aria role and attributes as any valid attribute is passed to the list element. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

sections.label: Alignment
sections.description: Content location relative the line is defined with the align property.

examples.basic:
<p-timeline [value]="events" class="w-full md:w-80">
    <ng-template #content let-event>
        {{ event.status }}
    </ng-template>
</p-timeline>
<p-timeline [value]="events" class="w-full md:w-80" align="right">
    <ng-template #content let-event>
        {{ event.status }}
    </ng-template>
</p-timeline>
<p-timeline [value]="events" class="w-full md:w-80" align="alternate">
    <ng-template #content let-event>
        {{ event.status }}
    </ng-template>
</p-timeline>
examples.html: {{ event.status }} {{ event.status }} {{ event.status }}

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Timeline receives the events with the value property as a collection of arbitrary objects. In addition, content template is required to display the representation of an event. Example below is a sample events array that is used throughout the documentation.

examples.basic:
<p-timeline [value]="events">
    <ng-template #content let-event>
        {{ event.status }}
    </ng-template>
</p-timeline>
examples.html: {{ event.status }}

sections.label: Horizontal
sections.description: TimeLine orientation is controlled with the layout property, default is vertical having horizontal as the alternative.

examples.basic: {{ event }} {{ event }} {{ event }}
examples.html: {{ event }} {{ event }} {{ event }}

sections.label: Opposite
sections.description: Additional content at the other side of the line can be provided with the opposite property.

examples.basic:
<p-timeline [value]="events">
    <ng-template #opposite let-event>
        <small class="text-surface-500 dark:text-surface-400">{{ event.date }}</small>
    </ng-template>
    <ng-template #content let-event>
        {{ event.status }}
    </ng-template>
</p-timeline>
examples.html: {{ event.date }} {{ event.status }}

sections.description: Sample implementation with custom content and styled markers.

components.name: toast
components.title: Angular Toast Component
components.description: Toast is used to display messages in an overlay.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Toast component use alert role that implicitly defines aria-live as "assertive" and aria-atomic as "true". Close element is a button with an aria-label that refers to the aria.close property of the locale API by default. Close Button Keyboard Support Key Function enter Closes the message. space Closes the message.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Toasts are displayed by calling the add and addAll method provided by the messageService . A single toast is specified by the Message interface that defines various properties such as severity , summary and detail .

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-button (onClick)="show()" label="Show" />

sections.label: clear-doc
sections.description: Clicking the close icon on the toast, removes it manually. Same can also be achieved programmatically using the clear function of the messageService . Calling it without any arguments, removes all displayed messages whereas calling it with a key, removes the messages displayed on a toast having the same key.

examples.basic:
<p-toast key="myKey" />
<p-button (click)="show()" label="Show" />
<p-button (click)="clear()" label="Clear" severity="secondary" />

sections.label: Headless
sections.description: Headless mode allows you to customize the entire user interface instead of the default elements.

examples.basic: {{ message.summary }}
examples.html: {{ message.summary }}

sections.label: life-doc
sections.description: A toast disappears after 3000ms by default, set the life option on either the message or toast to override this.

examples.basic:
<p-toast [life]="10000" />
<p-button (click)="showLife()" label="Show Life" />
<p-button (click)="showLifeLong()" label="Show Life Long" />

sections.label: Multiple
sections.description: Multiple toasts are displayed by passing an array to the showAll method of the messageService .

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-button pRipple (click)="show()" label="Multiple" severity="warn" />

sections.label: Position
sections.description: Location of the toast is customized with the position property. Valid values are top-left , top-center , top-right , bottom-left , bottom-center , bottom-right and center .

sections.label: Responsive
sections.description: Toast styling can be adjusted per screen size with the breakpoints option. The value of breakpoints should be an object literal whose keys are the maximum screen sizes and values are the styles per screen.

examples.basic:
<p-toast [breakpoints]="{ '920px': { width: '50%', right: 'auto' } }" />
<p-button (click)="show()" label="Show" />

sections.label: Severity
sections.description: The severity option specifies the type of the message. There are four types of messages: success , info , warn and error . The severity of the message is used to display the icon and the color of the toast.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showSuccess()" label="Success" severity="success" />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showInfo()" label="Info" severity="info" />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showWarn()" label="Warn" severity="warn" />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showError()" label="Error" severity="danger" />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showSecondary()" label="Secondary" severity="secondary" />
<p-button type="button" pRipple (click)="showContrast()" label="Contrast" severity="contrast" />

sections.label: Sticky
sections.description: A toast disappears after the time defined by the life option, set sticky option true on the message to override this and not hide the toast automatically.

sections.label: target-doc
sections.description: A page may have multiple toast components, in case you'd like to target a specific message to a particular toast, use the key property so that toast and the message can match.

examples.basic:
<p-toast key="toast1" />
<p-toast key="toast2" />
<p-button (click)="showToast1()" label="Show Success" />
<p-button (click)="showToast2()" label="Show Warning" severity="warn" />

sections.label: template-doc
sections.description: Templating allows customizing the content where the message instance is available as the implicit variable.

examples.basic:
Amy Elsner
{{ message.summary }}
examples.html:
Amy Elsner
{{ message.summary }}

components.name: togglebutton
components.title: Angular ToggleButton Component
components.description: ToggleButton is used to select a boolean value using a button.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader ToggleButton component uses an element with button role and updates aria-pressed state for screen readers. Value to describe the component can be defined with ariaLabelledBy or ariaLabel props, it is highly suggested to use either of these props as the component changes the label displayed which will result in screen readers to read different labels when the component receives focus. To prevent this, always provide an aria label that does not change related to state.

examples.basic: Remember Me

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Two-way binding to a boolean property is defined using the standard ngModel directive.

examples.basic: <p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="checked" onLabel="On" offLabel="Off" class="w-24" />

sections.label: Customized
sections.description: Icons and Labels can be customized using onLabel , offLabel , onIcon and offIcon properties.

examples.basic: <p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="checked" onLabel="Locked" offLabel="Unlocked" onIcon="pi pi-check" offIcon="pi pi-times" onIcon="pi pi-lock" offIcon="pi pi-lock-open" class="w-36" ariaLabel="Do you confirm" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <p-togglebutton disabled="true" onIcon="pi pi-check" offIcon="pi pi-times" [(ngModel)]="checked" onLabel="Yes" offLabel="No" class="w-full sm:w-40" ariaLabel="Confirmation" />

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="checked" onLabel="On" offLabel="Off" fluid />

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: The invalid state is applied using the invalid property to indicate failed validation, which can be integrated with Angular Forms.

examples.basic: <p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="checked" onIcon="pi pi-check" offIcon="pi pi-times" [invalid]="!checked" class="w-full sm:w-40" aria-label="Confirmation" />

sections.label: reactiveforms-doc
sections.description: ToggleButton can also be used with reactive forms. In this case, the formControlName property is used to bind the component to a form control.

examples.basic: @if (isInvalid('checked')) { Consent is mandatory. }
examples.html: @if (isInvalid('checked')) { Consent is mandatory. }

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: ToggleButton provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

examples.basic:
<p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="value1" onLabel="On" offLabel="Off" size="small" class="min-w-16" />
<p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="value2" onLabel="On" offLabel="Off" class="min-w-20" />
<p-togglebutton [(ngModel)]="value3" onLabel="On" offLabel="Off" size="large" class="min-w-24" />
@if (model.invalid && (model.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Consent is mandatory. }
examples.html: @if (model.invalid && (model.touched || exampleForm.submitted)) { Consent is mandatory. }

components.name: toggleswitch
components.title: Angular ToggleSwitch Component
components.description: ToggleSwitch is used to select a boolean value.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader InputSwitch component uses a hidden native checkbox element with switch role internally that is only visible to screen readers. Value to describe the component can either be provided via label tag combined with inputId prop or using ariaLabelledBy , ariaLabel props.

examples.basic: Remember Me

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Two-way value binding is defined using ngModel .

examples.basic: <p-toggleswitch [(ngModel)]="checked" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <p-toggleswitch [(ngModel)]="checked" [disabled]="true" />

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: The invalid state is applied using the invalid property to indicate failed validation, which can be integrated with Angular Forms.

examples.basic: <p-toggleswitch [(ngModel)]="checked" [invalid]="!checked" />

sections.label: Preselection
sections.description: Enabling ngModel property displays the component as active initially.

examples.basic: <p-toggleswitch [(ngModel)]="checked" />

sections.label: reactiveforms-doc
sections.description: ToggleSwitch can also be used with reactive forms. In this case, the formControlName property is used to bind the component to a form control.

examples.basic: @if (isInvalid('activation')) { Activation is required. }
examples.html: @if (isInvalid('activation')) { Activation is required. }

sections.label: Template
sections.description: The handle template is available to display custom content.

examples.basic: @if (model.invalid && exampleForm.submitted) { Activation is required. }
examples.html: @if (model.invalid && exampleForm.submitted) { Activation is required. }

components.name: toolbar
components.title: Angular Toolbar Component
components.description: Toolbar is a grouping component for buttons and other content.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Toolbar uses toolbar role for the root element, aria-orientation is not included as it defaults to horizontal . Any valid attribute is passed to the root element so you may add additional properties like aria-labelledby and aria-labelled to define the element if required. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements. Arbitrary content can be placed with templating and elements like buttons inside should follow the page tab sequence.

examples.html:
<p-toolbar aria-label="Actions">
    Content
</p-toolbar>

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Toolbar is a grouping component for buttons and other content. Its content can be placed inside the start , center and end sections.

examples.basic:
<p-toolbar>
    <ng-template #start>
        <p-button icon="pi pi-plus" class="mr-2" text severity="secondary" />
        <p-button icon="pi pi-print" class="mr-2" text severity="secondary" />
        <p-button icon="pi pi-upload" text severity="secondary" />
    </ng-template>
    <ng-template #center>
        <p-iconfield iconPosition="left">
            <p-inputicon class="pi pi-search" />
            <input type="text" pInputText placeholder="Search" />
        </p-iconfield>
    </ng-template>
    <ng-template #end>
        <p-splitbutton label="Save" [model]="items" />
    </ng-template>
</p-toolbar>

sections.label: Custom
sections.description: Content can also be placed using the start , center and end templates.

examples.typescript:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { AvatarModule } from 'primeng/avatar'; import { ButtonModule } from 'primeng/button'; import { ToolbarModule } from 'primeng/toolbar'; @Component({ template: `
`, standalone: true, imports: [AvatarModule, ButtonModule, ToolbarModule] }) export class ToolbarCustomDemo {}

components.name: tooltip
components.title: Angular Tooltip Component
components.description: Tooltip directive provides advisory information for a component. Tooltip is integrated within various PrimeNG components.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Tooltip component uses tooltip role and when it becomes visible the generated id of the tooltip is defined as the aria-describedby of the target. Keyboard Support Key Function escape Closes the tooltip when focus is on the target.

sections.label: Auto Hide
sections.description: Tooltip is hidden when mouse leaves the target element, in cases where tooltip needs to be interacted with, set autoHide to false to change the default behavior.

examples.basic:
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" [autoHide]="false" placeholder="autoHide: false" />
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" placeholder="autoHide: true" />

sections.label: Custom
sections.description: Tooltip can use either a string or a TemplateRef .

examples.typescript:
import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { ButtonModule } from 'primeng/button'; import { TooltipModule } from 'primeng/tooltip'; @Component({ template: `
PrimeNG rocks!
`, standalone: true, imports: [ButtonModule, TooltipModule] }) export class TooltipCustomDemo {}

sections.label: Delay
sections.description: Adding delays to the show and hide events are defined with showDelay and hideDelay options respectively.

examples.basic: <p-button pTooltip="Confirm to proceed" showDelay="1000" hideDelay="300" label="Save" />

sections.label: Event
sections.description: Tooltip gets displayed on hover event of its target by default, other option is the focus event to display and blur to hide.

examples.basic: <input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" tooltipEvent="focus" placeholder="focus to display tooltip" />

sections.label: Tooltip Options
sections.description: Tooltip is also configurable by using tooltipOptions property.

examples.basic: <input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" [tooltipOptions]="tooltipOptions" placeholder="hover to display tooltip" />

sections.label: Position
sections.description: Position of the tooltip is specified using tooltipPosition attribute. Valid values are top , bottom , right and left . Default position of the tooltip is right .

examples.basic:
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" tooltipPosition="right" placeholder="Right" />
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" tooltipPosition="top" placeholder="Top" />
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" tooltipPosition="bottom" placeholder="Bottom" />
<input type="text" pInputText pTooltip="Enter your username" tooltipPosition="left" placeholder="Left" />

props.name: positionLeft

props.name: autoHide

props.name: fitContent

props.name: hideOnEscape

props.name: content

props.name: disabled

props.name: tooltipOptions

props.name: appendTo
props.description: Target element to attach the overlay, valid values are "body" or a local ng-template variable of another element (note: use binding with brackets for template variables, e.g. [appendTo]="mydiv" for a div element having #mydiv as variable name).

props.name: pTooltipPT

components.name: tree
components.title: Angular Tree Component
components.description: Tree is used to display hierarchical data.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Value to describe the component can either be provided with aria-labelledby or aria-label props. The root list element has a tree role whereas each list item has a treeitem role along with aria-label , aria-selected and aria-expanded attributes. In checkbox selection, aria-checked is used instead of aria-selected . The container element of a treenode has the group role. Checkbox and toggle icons are hidden from screen readers as their parent element with treeitem role and attributes are used instead for readers and keyboard support. The aria-setsize , aria-posinset and aria-level attributes are calculated implicitly and added to each treeitem. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the first selected node when focus enters the component, if there is none then first element receives the focus. If focus is already inside the component, moves focus to the next focusable element in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Moves focus to the last selected node when focus enters the component, if there is none then first element receives the focus. If focus is already inside the component, moves focus to the previous focusable element in the page tab sequence. enter Selects the focused treenode. space Selects the focused treenode. down arrow Moves focus to the next treenode. up arrow Moves focus to the previous treenode. right arrow If node is closed, opens the node otherwise moves focus to the first child node. left arrow If node is open, closes the node otherwise moves focus to the parent node.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Tree component requires an array of TreeNode objects as its value .

examples.basic: <p-tree [value]="files()" class="w-full md:w-[30rem]" />

sections.label: Checkbox
sections.description: Selection of multiple nodes via checkboxes is enabled by configuring selectionMode as checkbox .

examples.basic: <p-tree [value]="files()" selectionMode="checkbox" class="w-full md:w-[30rem]" [(selection)]="selectedFiles" />

sections.label: Context Menu
sections.description: Tree has exclusive integration with ContextMenu using the contextMenu property along with the contextMenuSelection to manage the selection.

examples.basic:
<p-toast [style]="{ marginTop: '80px' }" />
<p-tree [value]="files()" class="w-full md:w-80" selectionMode="single" [(selection)]="selectedNode" [(contextMenuSelection)]="contextMenuNode" [contextMenu]="cm" contextMenuSelectionMode="separate" />
<p-contextmenu #cm [model]="items" />

sections.label: Controlled
sections.description: Tree requires a collection of TreeNode instances as a value .

sections.label: Events
sections.description: An event is provided for each type of user interaction such as expand, collapse and selection.

examples.basic:
<p-toast />
<p-tree
    [value]="files()"
    class="w-full md:w-[30rem]"
    selectionMode="single"
    [(selection)]="selectedFile"
    (onNodeExpand)="nodeExpand($event)"
    (onNodeCollapse)="nodeCollapse($event)"
    (onNodeSelect)="nodeSelect($event)"
    (onNodeUnselect)="nodeUnselect($event)"
/>

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: Filtering is enabled by adding the filter property, by default label property of a node is used to compare against the value in the text field, in order to customize which field(s) should be used during search define filterBy property. In addition filterMode specifies the filtering strategy. In lenient mode when the query matches a node, children of the node are not searched further as all descendants of the node are included. On the other hand, in strict mode when the query matches a node, filtering continues on all descendants.

sections.label: Lazy
sections.description: Lazy loading is useful when dealing with huge datasets, in this example nodes are dynamically loaded on demand using loading property and onNodeExpand method.

examples.basic: <p-tree class="w-full md:w-[30rem]" [value]="nodes()" loadingMode="icon" (onNodeExpand)="onNodeExpand($event)" />

sections.label: Multiple
sections.description: More than one node is selectable by setting selectionMode to multiple . By default in multiple selection mode, metaKey press (e.g.  ) is necessary to add to existing selections however this can be configured with disabling the metaKeySelection property. Note that in touch enabled devices, Tree always ignores metaKey. In multiple selection mode, value binding should be a key-value pair where key is the node key and value is a boolean to indicate selection.

sections.label: Single
sections.description: Single node selection is configured by setting selectionMode as single along with selection properties to manage the selection value binding.

examples.basic: <p-tree [value]="files()" class="w-full md:w-[30rem]" selectionMode="single" [(selection)]="selectedFile" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Custom node content instead of a node label is defined with the pTemplate property.

examples.basic: {{ node.label }} {{ node.label }}
examples.html: {{ node.label }} {{ node.label }}

sections.label: Virtual Scroll
sections.description: VirtualScroller is a performance-approach to handle huge data efficiently. Setting virtualScroll property as true and providing a virtualScrollItemSize in pixels would be enough to enable this functionality.

examples.basic: <p-tree [value]="nodes()" scrollHeight="250px" [virtualScroll]="true" [virtualScrollItemSize]="35" />

sections.label: virtualscrolllazy-doc
sections.description: VirtualScroller is a performance-approach to handle huge data efficiently. Setting virtualScroll property as true and providing a virtualScrollItemSize in pixels would be enough to enable this functionality.

examples.basic: <p-tree [value]="nodes()" scrollHeight="250px" [virtualScroll]="true" [lazy]="true" [virtualScrollItemSize]="35" (onNodeExpand)="nodeExpand($event)" [loading]="loading()" />

components.name: treeselect
components.title: Angular TreeSelect Component
components.description: TreeSelect is a form component to choose from hierarchical data.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Value to describe the component can either be provided with ariaLabelledby or ariaLabel props. The treeselect element has a combobox role in addition to aria-haspopup and aria-expanded attributes. The relation between the combobox and the popup is created with aria-controls that refers to the id of the popup. The popup list has an id that refers to the aria-controls attribute of the combobox element and uses tree as the role. Each list item has a treeitem role along with aria-label , aria-selected and aria-expanded attributes. In checkbox selection, aria-checked is used instead of aria-selected . Checkbox and toggle icons are hidden from screen readers as their parent element with treeitem role and attributes are used instead for readers and keyboard support. The container element of a treenode has the group role. The aria-setsize , aria-posinset and aria-level attributes are calculated implicitly and added to each treeitem. If filtering is enabled, filterInputProps can be defined to give aria-* props to the filter input element.

examples.basic: Options

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: TreeSelect is used as a controlled component with ng-model directive along with an options collection. Internally Tree component is used so the options model is based on TreeNode API. In single selection mode, value binding should be the key value of a node.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="md:w-80 w-full" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Select Item" />

sections.label: Checkbox
sections.description: Selection of multiple nodes via checkboxes is enabled by configuring selectionMode as checkbox .

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="w-full md:w-80" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" display="chip" [metaKeySelection]="false" selectionMode="checkbox" placeholder="Select Item" />

sections.label: Clear Icon
sections.description: When showClear is enabled, a clear icon is displayed to clear the value.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Select Item" class="md:w-80 w-full" [showClear]="true" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="md:w-80 w-full" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" [disabled]="true" placeholder="TreeSelect" />

sections.label: Filled
sections.description: Specify the variant property as filled to display the component with a higher visual emphasis than the default outlined style.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="md:w-80 w-full" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" variant="filled" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Select Item" />

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: Filtering is enabled by adding the filter property, by default label property of a node is used to compare against the value in the text field, in order to customize which field(s) should be used during search define filterBy property. In addition filterMode specifies the filtering strategy. In lenient mode when the query matches a node, children of the node are not searched further as all descendants of the node are included. On the other hand, in strict mode when the query matches a node, filtering continues on all descendants.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="md:w-80 w-full" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Select Item" [filter]="true" [filterInputAutoFocus]="true" />

sections.label: Float Label
sections.description: A floating label appears on top of the input field when focused. Visit FloatLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<p-floatlabel class="w-full md:w-80">
    <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value1" inputId="over_label" [options]="nodes" class="w-full" />
    <label for="over_label">Over Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>
<p-floatlabel class="w-full md:w-80" variant="in">
    <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value2" inputId="in_label" [options]="nodes" class="w-full" />
    <label for="in_label">In Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>
<p-floatlabel class="w-full md:w-80" variant="on">
    <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value3" inputId="on_label" [options]="nodes" class="w-full" />
    <label for="on_label">On Label</label>
</p-floatlabel>

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Select Item" fluid />

sections.label: Ifta Label
sections.description: IftaLabel is used to create infield top aligned labels. Visit IftaLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<p-iftalabel class="w-full md:w-80">
    <p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="selectedValue" inputId="t_file" [options]="nodes" class="w-full" />
    <label for="t_file">File</label>
</p-iftalabel>

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: The invalid state is applied using the invalid property to indicate failed validation, which can be integrated with Angular Forms.

examples.basic:
<p-treeselect [invalid]="selectedValue1 === undefined" [(ngModel)]="selectedValue1" [options]="nodes" placeholder="TreeSelect" class="md:w-80 w-full" />
<p-treeselect [invalid]="selectedValue2 === undefined" [(ngModel)]="selectedValue2" [options]="nodes" placeholder="TreeSelect" class="md:w-80 w-full" />

sections.label: Lazy
sections.description: Lazy loading is useful when dealing with huge datasets, in this example nodes are dynamically loaded on demand using loading property and onNodeExpand method.

examples.basic:
<p-treeselect
    class="w-full md:w-80"
    [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes"
    (onNodeExpand)="onNodeExpand($event)"
    [options]="nodes()"
    display="chip"
    [metaKeySelection]="false"
    selectionMode="checkbox"
    placeholder="Select Item"
    [loading]="loading"
    loadingMode="icon"
/>

sections.label: Multiple
sections.description: More than one node is selectable by setting selectionMode to multiple . By default in multiple selection mode, metaKey press (e.g.  ) is necessary to add to existing selections however this can be configured with disabling the metaKeySelection property. Note that in touch enabled devices, TreeSelect always ignores metaKey. In multiple selection mode, value binding should be a key-value pair where key is the node key and value is a boolean to indicate selection.

examples.basic: <p-treeselect class="w-full md:w-80" [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes" [options]="nodes" [metaKeySelection]="false" selectionMode="multiple" placeholder="Select Item" />

sections.label: reactiveforms-doc
sections.description: TreeSelect can also be used with reactive forms. In this case, the formControlName property is used to bind the component to a form control.

examples.basic: @if (isInvalid('selectedNodes')) { Selection is required. }
examples.html: @if (isInvalid('selectedNodes')) { Selection is required. }

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: TreeSelect provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

examples.basic:
<p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value1" [options]="nodes" size="small" placeholder="Small" class="md:w-80 w-full" />
<p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value2" [options]="nodes" placeholder="Normal" class="md:w-80 w-full" />
<p-treeselect [(ngModel)]="value3" [options]="nodes" size="large" placeholder="Large" class="md:w-80 w-full" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: TreeSelect offers multiple templates for customization through templating.

examples.basic: Available Files
examples.html: Available Files

examples.basic: @if (node.invalid && exampleForm.submitted) { Selection is required. }
examples.html: @if (node.invalid && exampleForm.submitted) { Selection is required. }

sections.label: virtualscroll-doc
sections.description: VirtualScrolling is an efficient way of rendering the options by displaying a small subset of data in the viewport at any time. When dealing with huge number of options, it is suggested to enable VirtualScrolling to avoid performance issues. Usage is simple as setting virtualScroll property to true and defining virtualScrollItemSize to specify the height of an item.

examples.basic:
<p-treeselect
    class="w-full md:w-80"
    [(ngModel)]="selectedNodes"
    [options]="nodes"
    display="chip"
    [metaKeySelection]="false"
    selectionMode="checkbox"
    placeholder="Select Item"
    [virtualScroll]="true"
    [virtualScrollItemSize]="35"
    [virtualScrollOptions]="{ scrollHeight: '200px' }"
></p-treeselect>

components.name: treetable
components.title: Angular TreeTable Component
components.description: TreeTable is used to display hierarchical data in tabular format.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Default role of the table is table . Header, body and footer elements use rowgroup , rows use row role, header cells have columnheader and body cells use cell roles. Sortable headers utilizer aria-sort attribute either set to "ascending" or "descending". Row elements manage aria-expanded for state and aria-level attribute to define the hierachy by ttRow directive. Table rows and table cells should be specified by users using the aria-posinset , aria-setsize , aria-label , and aria-describedby attributes, as they are determined through templating. When selection is enabled, ttSelectableRow directive sets aria-selected to true on a row. In checkbox mode, the built-in checkbox component use checkbox role with aria-checked state attribute. Editable cells use custom templating so you need to manage aria roles and attributes manually if required. Paginator is a standalone component used inside the TreeTable, refer to the paginator for more information about the accessibility features. Sortable Headers Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves through the headers. enter Sorts the column. space Sorts the column. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the first selected node when focus enters the component, if there is none then first element receives the focus. If focus is already inside the component, moves focus to the next focusable element in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Moves focus to the last selected node when focus enters the component, if there is none then first element receives the focus. If focus is already inside the component, moves focus to the previous focusable element in the page tab sequence. enter Selects the focused treenode. space Selects the focused treenode. down arrow Moves focus to the next treenode. up arrow Moves focus to the previous treenode. right arrow If node is closed, opens the node otherwise moves focus to the first child node. left arrow If node is open, closes the node otherwise moves focus to the parent node.

sections.label: Context Menu
sections.description: TreeTable has exclusive integration with contextmenu component. In order to attach a menu to a table, add ttContextMenuRow directive to the rows that can be selected with context menu, define a local template variable for the menu and bind it to the contextMenu property of the table. This enables displaying the menu whenever a row is right clicked. A separate contextMenuSelection property is used to get a hold of the right clicked row. For dynamic columns, setting ttContextMenuRowDisabled property as true disables context menu for that particular row.

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: The filterMode specifies the filtering strategy, in lenient mode when the query matches a node, children of the node are not searched further as all descendants of the node are included. On the other hand, in strict mode when the query matches a node, filtering continues on all descendants. A general filled called filterGlobal is also provided to search all columns that support filtering.

sections.label: Lazy Load
sections.description: Lazy mode is handy to deal with large datasets, instead of loading the entire data, small chunks of data is loaded by invoking corresponding callbacks everytime paging , sorting and filtering occurs. Sample below imitates lazy loading data from a remote datasource using an in-memory list and timeouts to mimic network connection. Enabling the lazy property and assigning the logical number of rows to totalRecords by doing a projection query are the key elements of the implementation so that paginator displays the UI assuming there are actually records of totalRecords size although in reality they are not present on page, only the records that are displayed on the current page exist. In addition, only the root elements should be loaded, children can be loaded on demand using onNodeExpand callback.
